either dust with icing sugar or marzipan and icing. 450g box marzipan2 tbsp sieved apricot jam warmed350g icing sugar sieved50ml lemon juice25g caster sugar brush the cake all over with the warmed apricot jam. roll out the marzipan; roll one third to a circle to fit the top. roll out the remaining two thirds to a strip to fit the sides of the cake. lay the top piece on and press down. gently wrap the strip round the side press on and trim. the cake can be left for 24 hours uncovered before icing if convenient. stand it on a serving plate or board. for the icing place the icing sugar in a large bowl. put the lemon juice and caster sugar in a small saucepan. heat gently and allow the sugar to dissolve then bring to the boil and pour into the icing sugar beating well. when smooth use to ice the top and sides of the cake immediately. allow to stand for 24 hours to allow the icing to harden before decorating and serving. make this cake simply just with buttercream icing and a dusting of icing sugar or ice with a soft frosting with in this case a lemon flavour. this can be made and iced up to 5 days before it is needed.

split the cake horizontally into 3 layers. divide the buttercream between two portions spread over evenly and reassemble the cake. either dust with icing sugar or marzipan and icing. 450g box marzipan2 tbsp sieved apricot jam warmed350g icing sugar sieved50ml lemon juice25g caster sugar brush the cake all over with the warmed apricot jam. roll out the marzipan; roll one third to a circle to fit the top. roll out the remaining two thirds to a strip to fit the sides of the cake. lay the top piece on and press down. gently wrap the strip round the side press on and trim. the cake can be left for 24 hours uncovered before icing if convenient. stand it on a serving plate or board. for the icing place the icing sugar in a large bowl. put the lemon juice and caster sugar in a small saucepan. heat gently and allow the sugar to dissolve then bring to the boil and pour into the icing sugar beating well. when smooth use to ice the top and sides of the cake immediately. allow to stand for 24 hours to allow the icing to harden before decorating and serving. make this cake simply just with buttercream icing and a dusting of icing sugar or ice with a soft frosting with in this case a lemon flavour. this can be made and iced up to 5 days before it is needed.

recipedetails: start off by preparing the vegetables. i like to add a little carrot strips for colour. get one of those special peelers that cut finely julienned strips of carrots. they are incredible. slice spring onions into fine thin strips. cut some large slices of iceberg lettuce. get some fresh basil and mint. use only the leaves in whole pieces. boil a large pot of water. cook some rice noodles according to the package's instructions. i've used both fat rice noodles and skinny ones with success. so it really doesn't matter what kind you use. next
label: get some bacon. i'm lazy to slice fresh pork
column3: so i use a good smoked shoulder bacon that are ready to use flat pieces of pork and has a wonderful flavour. pick the kind that are in large sheets with as little fat as possible. cook the bacon in the boiling water. don't cook for too long. once they turn pink
column4: remove them from the water. i dump in the shrimp too. yes
column5: all in the same pot. it really doesn't matter. cut off visble bits of fat from the pork and slice them into half to get long strips. slice the shrimps horizontally into half. now we are ready to roll. prepare a large bowl of warm water. not boiling water. make sure you can dip your hands into it. slice a sheet of rice paper into the water. count to 3 and lift it out. do not soak the paper in the water. it should be stiff when you lift it out of the water. lay the rice sheet on a large plate. don't worry that it still feels stiff at this point. it will soften by the time you roll it. lay the shrimp first to create a curved flat surface that will look nicer when the roll is complete. add slices of bacon on top. add the lettuce. then the basil. add the mint
column6: carrots and spring onions. top with a small bit of noodles. do not over fill the roll. when there are too many ingredients
column7: they make it really hard to roll nicely and the sides may break open. it's better to make more rolls than distorted looking ultra fat rolls. this is how you roll. lift the front part of the rice sheet over the ingredients. tuck the ingredients in with your fingers. pull one side of the sheet over. and then the other side. finish by rolling over the rest of the rice sheet. lay the spring rolls on a tray or plate and cover with a clean damp cloth or cling-wrap film. keep them chilled in the fridge until ready to eat. now
column8: make the peanut dipping sauce. add one part of hoisin sauce to a saucepan. i usually use 4 tablespoons. add one part of water. i usually add 4 tablespoons of water. add 1/2 part of sesame oil. i usually add 2 tablespoons. add 1/2 part of shaoxing huatiao wine. i usually add 2 tablespoons. if you have no idea what this wine is
column9: use this picture to find it in asian stores. the 3 words in yellow says “hua tiao jiu”
column10: which means hua tiao wine. place the saucepan over a low heat and whisk gently to combine. when the sauce starts to simmer
column11: it's ready. do not boil. set the sauce aside in a bowl and place in the fridge to chill. in the meantime
column12: place one part of salted roasted peanuts in a food processor. i usually use 4 tablespoons of peanuts. whisk the processor till the peanuts are finely ground. when you are ready to serve the spring rolls
column13: add the ground peanuts to the sauce and stir well to combine. the sauce is ready to use. serve the rolls with the peanut sauce.

recipedetails: now we are ready to roll. prepare a large bowl of warm water. not boiling water. make sure you can dip your hands into it. slice a sheet of rice paper into the water. count to 3 and lift it out. do not soak the paper in the water. it should be stiff when you lift it out of the water. lay the rice sheet on a large plate. don't worry that it still feels stiff at this point. it will soften by the time you roll it. lay the shrimp first to create a curved flat surface that will look nicer when the roll is complete. add slices of bacon on top. add the lettuce. then the basil. add the mint

column9: and scrape until the mixture is smooth and the lemons pieces are no longer visible. add the rest of the ingredients and blend until everything is thoroughly combined. rap the blender/bowl on the counter a few times to get rid of any air bubbles. pour the mixture into the partially baked crust. it will be very full! carefully transfer the baking sheet to the oven. bake for 20 minutes. after 20 minutes increase the oven temp. to 350f. and continue to bake for an additional 25-30 minutes. i had to bake mine for about 35. don't worry if the lemon bubbles over the crust. you will know it is ready to take out of the oven when the lemon mixture is set and slightly shaky in the middle. transfer to a cooling rack and allow it to come to room temp. this is best served on the day it is made. garnish with some sifted powdered sugar if desired.
